doc://com.apple.documentation/documentat.title: Creating a PDF with a PDF Renderer

abstract.text: An abstract base class for creating graphics renderers.
Creates a new graphics renderer with the specified bounds and format.
A closure for drawing PDF content.
A set of drawing attributes that represents the configuration of a graphics renderer context.
A graphics renderer for creating Core Graphics-backed images.
The drawing environment for an image renderer.
A set of drawing attributes that represents the configuration of an image renderer context.

inlineContent.text: You can use PDF renderers to create PDF files, without having to manage Core Graphics contexts.
To render a PDF:
Optionally create a
object to specify nondefault parameters the renderer should use to create its context.
Instantiate a
object, providing the dimensions of the output image and a format object. The renderer uses sensible defaults for the current device if you don't provide format object, as demonstrated in
Choose one of the rendering methods depending on your desired output:
outputs the PDF in the form of a
object, and
saves the PDF as a file directly to disk.
Provide Core Graphics drawing instructions within the closure associated with your chosen method, as shown in
Optionally, you can create a multi-page PDF, using the approach shown in
Optionally, add links to your PDF to make navigation easy, as shown in
Once a PDF renderer is initialized, you can use it to draw multiple PDFs with the same configuration.
Create a PDF renderer, providing the bounds of the PDF page.

abstract.text: Creating a PDF renderer

inlineContent.text: You can instead use one of the other
initializers to specify a renderer format (
) in addition to the bounds. This allows you to configure the underlying Core Graphics context with custom PDF document info. If you don't provide a format, the
format is used, which creates a context best suited for the current device.

content.text: Creating a PDF with a PDF Renderer

inlineContent.text: Use the

method to create a PDF with the PDF renderer you created above. This takes a block that represents the drawing actions. Within this block, the renderer creates a Core Graphics context using the parameters provided when the renderer was initialized, and sets this to be the current context.
Before issuing PDF drawing instructions, you must create a page with a call to either the

abstract.text: Adding multiple pages to a PDF

inlineContent.text: You can create internal links, known as destinations, in PDFs. A complete link is made up of two components:
A named destination. This is simply a point on a PDF page. You create these with the
method on
A link region. This is a rectangle on a PDF page, which when tapped, instructs the PDF viewing app to jump to a specific named destination. You create these with the
method on
, providing the name of the destination to jump to, and the bounds of the active link region.
The code in
demonstrates how to use destinations with a PDF renderer by showing how to create links that jump to the next page.

abstract.text: Using destinations in a PDF renderer

inlineContent.text: The code in
adds large red labels that when clicked will jump from the current page to the next page. Each page has a destination with names of the form
, positioned at the origin. The bounding box for the next-page label is used as the link to the destination on the following page.
The
and
methods on
use the underlying PDF coordinate space, which has its y-axis flipped with respect to the coordinate system used by Core Graphics. You can translate between the two using the
property on
